I'd build some trust beforehand. Talk to her a couple of times before asking her out so you're not total strangers to each other.
The biggest factor in increasing your chances is good timing. You should get to know her enough so that she's not a complete stranger, but not so much that she's become a friend. Then you must be upfront and not hesitant, make it clear that you're asking her out, and don't try to mask it as a friendly outing to increase your chances. If she likes you, she'll probably say yes, and if she doesn't like you, you can't really do much about it.

Conversations through text can very easily bore someone.
I'm not sure how old you are but say if you and said woman are over 25+
They will most likely not be interested in lengthy conversations through text unless you're already important in their lives.
If you're on the younger side, you have more freedom since the zoomer crowd love to text 24/7.
But in terms of you feeling like you're always left on read; I have spoken to women through dm's and sometimes the conversation is just so dry there's no point in continuing.
Other times the conversation flows so naturally it's perfect.
It's a matter of chance really. Someone out there will enjoy conversations with you and others will send 1 message and never reply. Just it what it is.
Now if you tell me that literally every single woman has left you on read, you might want to switch up how you talk through text. Keep it light hearted and throw in jokes/memes without trying too hard.

I do not want money, I don't need much of it. I just want to read books and use my body, rather than rot in a chair. I have always been interested in the military and am tempted to join.
My two choices are: white collar job that pays well and satisfies those around me but rots my mind and body, and ends with a bang in my early 30s. I had that sense when I was in high-school and followed me through-out college, which led me to drop out because it worsen with alcohol and drugs.

I eventually went to work in a high paced, high action enviroment, kinda like every man for himself but still worked as a team. I made many friends that taught introspective and character-building lessons that I never thought I would learn.

They taught me that self-image is important. People will see through a facade if obvious enough and you'll be gossiped about.

Never do something stupid you'll regret later.

Maintain a stoic personality and open up once you established a bond with the person or else they can backstab and they'll spill your beans if you open up too quickly.

Also work out, and build goals. My current is doing 100 pulls up and I'm half way there but I manage to build myself a body from it, and people notice and sort of admire it. Confidence is built.

If people mock you or you sense they will you can do three things. Ignore them, or Play along, or think about why you're being mocked and improve upon it.

F. Yeah, she's right. If she's asking to bring a friend, or asking if anyone else is coming, she's probably trying to feel out whether it's a date or not. If you allow/encourage it to be a group thing, you're probably confirming that and friendzoning yourself, so unless you trust your ability to flirt and lock a proper date down once you've got her in person, I'd be wary of going down that rout.

I'd just tell her "it's just gonna be us two" and see how that lands. If she's not interested and calls you on it, you can always spare your pride with a little "oh I didn't mean you COULDN'T invite anyone else, just that I HAND'T yet lolol." She'll see through it, but plausible deniability is a male superpower, it's all you need.
Disclaimer, I don't think you NEED to go the pride-sparing rout, you certainly don't need to do it for anyone else's benefit. But if having that safety net is what it takes for you to make the move in the first place, then keep it in your pocket.

>>28194474
I'm sure you've been told this before, but you are still SO young. I know it doesn't feel that way; I remember how I felt at 23, bemoaning the fact that I'd been out of highschool for 5 whole years, but you are SO SO young. Your lack of work history and romantic prospects means little to nothing at this point, as long as you PLAN AHEAD.

PLAN. MAKE A PLAN. I emphasize this because I remember how easy it was to accept empty platitudes of "oh you'll figure it out, you're still so young!" YOU HAVE TO HAVE A PLAN. It doesn't even need to be a complex plan - one thing at a time. In your case, you need to start with a job. That remote administrative job is not ideal, you need a job where you work with people in person to build connections. Knowing people is the single most important thing in this life. It is more important than a specific degree and is even more important than relevant knowledge of any trade. You HAVE to build connections with other people, even if they're surface-level. This can sound daunting, but most normies are actually pretty easy to get along with as long as you don't rant about weird shit like obscure anime with big-tiddy waifus.

Anyone can get on at a fast food joint and they often have open interviews; you should see several "now hiring" signs in your area unless you live in BFE. Literally go work at McDonald's or Taco Bell or something. You're not too good for it, a ton of people, myself included, have done their time in the food service industry. All you have to say is that you have a flexible schedule and are a quick learner and you'll be hired. Then you'll meet new people, through which you could also find new work opportunities, friends, and the potential for romance. Every job I've had since the age of 19 has been from knowing someone I met at previous jobs, and I'm currently 32 in a lucrative IT career that I enjoy, without a degree or formal certifications. THE MOST IMPORTANT THING YOU CAN DO IS MEET PEOPLE.

Going outside is a healthy habit that you should foster, and you did a really good job by at least trying it. It’s especially good that you prioritized eating, even if you didn’t like the food.

posts.com: How can I actually get and keep a good hobby? I keep jumping from interest to interest, I've tried out fishing, playing guitar, writing, and a bunch of others, but I just can't seem to keep them because my interest in them is short lived and I get bored. How can I get a hobby and keep it/become really good at it?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
First, sort out your short attention span. There's a difference between being bored and not being constantly over stimulated and getting a dopamine rush. Learn the difference.

Second, understand that it's ok to be bored sometimes. You won't always feel like doing your hobbies, that doesn't mean you should just drop them.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28196703
Get a cheap composition notebook and a pen/pencil, write down what you've tried so far and try and see if you can find a pattern in why you couldn't keep them? What caused you to lose interest?

For example, I tried out a lot of hobbies as well to see what stuck or not over the years, I didn't hold it against me if I got bored, it just meant I didn't like it but some patterns I found was, where can I do the hobby? If it required me leaving home, I was less likely to keep it up. What do I need to do the hobby? Painting needed expensive oil paints so I didn't keep up with it, stuck to paper and pencil sketching because of how cheap the materials are for just that. I was also learning Violin but it felt too expensive for up keep and I settled with just digital music production. Find the patterns, and brainstorm solutions. For me, it seem that for most hobbies, there was a digital equivalent that I could focus on instead and that help me keep up with it best

You have to look at any job application from the employers perspective. What is it that YOU can bring to THEM? How does hiring YOU benefit THEM? And here's the clincher, how does the benefits YOU bring stack up against or compete with ALL THE OTHER CANDIDATES?

Btw, "they get an employee" is not an answer to that question. Remember, a paper qualification is meaningless in 2023 without experience.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28101153
A job change isn't going to fix your life. You need an entire lifestyle change. I'm 26 and went through something similar around 24. I'm going to recommend something cliche, but it fucking works for reasons I will elaborate on. Get in shape. If you are fat lose weight. If you are skinny hit the gym. Yes it's a physical thing but we are mostly after the mental benefits. When you improve physically it does several things mentally (arguably it has more mental benefits than physical). First is you learn to be disciplined. This obviously effects every aspect of life. You need discipline to escape NEETdom. Next it will give you a taste of that "better life". You will see hard effort turn into tangible rewards that you can be proud of. This can set off a chain reaction into other aspects of life you feel are lacking. Next is confidence. You will be more confident in your self and your abilities and it could be enough of a boost to get you to pounce on opportunities you otherwise would have missed by being passive. Perhaps most important of all it will get you out of the house and give you a hobby that isn't doing anything for you. This can lead to meeting new people and gives you a common interest hobby that you can share and engage with most people over. Don't forget other people will treat you better too.

All of that doesn't even take into account the physical aspects that also play a role in mental health. You would likely see an increase in certain hormones such as testosterone and a decrease in things like estrogen. These hormones play a huge role in mental health and having screwed up hormones probably play a huge role in depression and the like. In my opinion physical improvement is the number one best thing you can do if you are unhappy with your life because it lays the foundation for everything else. This is coming from someone who was fat basically my entire life and was well on my way to being an eternal neet. Getting /fit/ is what saved me.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>28176244
I can't read it. My specific situation will not really relate to you.

The TL;DR is that I am an /out/ist through and through and nothing is going to change that.

I was in the army before college. Biology degree. Wildly depressed, and medicated for it. In college I did an internship with a conservation agency and it was fun, but I did the "right thing" and after school I just kept pursuing my "career path." Nothing glamorous or financially enticing, mind you. At 27 I had a paradigm shift, some major life changes (sister offed herself and ended a toxic 6 year relationship) and I took some seasonal /out/ work in Alaska to try and clear my heart and my head. Quit taking Zoloft during this time.

Following this, I left and did a "normal" job for about 1.25 years before I again felt the urge to get the fuck back outside. I worked for an environmental compliance contractor. I had a moment of clarity when a guy who had been there for 12 years told me he had a zoology degree. It made me sad to know he once shared my dreams. So I had to leave. Almost every person I knew told me that, at ~28 it was too late for a "career change" and I should just stay in place and effectively work at the same place until I died. I've since worked for a few different agencies/places for the feds doing /out/ things. I do not make much money. My job security is tenuous. But I feel at peace and wouldn't change it.

The point of my story is simply that if you recognize something you are truly passionate about, you should just stick with it, because trying to convince yourself you are happier in some other capacity just results in you being miserable. I wouldn't do something just to feel like you're moving forward, if that makes sense. I wouldn't do something you aren't "super passionate" about. Do not go be a cop simply because it is SOMETHING. Its your life, anon. 1/4 of it is over. Do you want to waste another 1/2 doing something you don't even give a shit about?

Seems to be either give up and work at Walmart or FoLoW yOuR pAsSiOn DrEaMs ReAlLy Do CoMe TrUe!!!!! Both approaches are idiotic and will waste more of your time. To put it as bluntly and simply as possible, passion projects are for trust fund kids, those who have already made it, and regular people who have exceptional talent and drive. The general rule is that if you were in the latter group, you would know by 25 ie you would already have been grinding for years at that point and you'd start to see success. Sorry to say, that's not you, so on to step two.

Step two is employment, which mostly sucks. Some people will tell you about how they have a passion for making other people rich, but they're mostly just coping. The purpose of employment is to GET CASH FLOW so you can either exit employment or at least have the funds to cope with it and stay sane. You should find something you're good at that you can tolerate without burning out that MAXIMIZES cash flow and pursue that. Ideally it should pay you to learn skills that you can deploy outside of employment so you can exit employment sooner rather than later. Think of employment as a bridge from virgin neetdom to chad neetdom. Some examples of viable options are trades, sales, it, coding meme, internet marketing. You can get an entry-level job in most of these fields with little-to-no experience. Grind certs, lie, just do whatever you need to do. Then start accruing skills that you can use for freelancing, consulting, contracting, ect in order to exit employment. If you really want to you can do your art fag stuff on the side, and if that blows up and you stop showing up to your job, more power to you.

posts.sub: Abusive step father is in the hospital. Mom wants me to visit him.
posts.com:
I want to get some insight on this situation so please share your thoughts.

Some backstory. My mom was a single parent. I don't know who my father is but my mom loved me and she did her best to send me to school and tried her hardest to raise me. Then my mom married when I was about 10 to a guy who we'll call Dave. Now, Dave was rich. He had two daughters himself (who we'll call B and C. B lived with us) Now, Dave was an awful awful man. He was physically and emotionally abusive. He changed my mom into hating me. I never had nice stuff to wear but B always had the cutest outfits. It gets worse, I had to litteraly beg my mom to buy me sanitary stuff so I could keep some stocked up instead of waiting till the worst possible day it. Their reasoning was that he's already doing me a favor by letting me live in his already gigantic house.

Dave's physical abuse was the most traumatising of the things he did. He always either beat me with a stick from a lemon tree we had in the yard or berate me with all sorts of foul language when something happened at school. One occasion I remember as the worst was when I was suspended from school because I pushed a bully and she hit her head on a desk. He broke almost half a dozen of sticks over my back. I remember waking up the day after and my pajamas sticking to my bottom because of the amount of skin he broke.

The first thing I did after I graduated from HS was moving to my own place. I hated all of them except my mom.

Now, a few years later my mom calls me saying that Dave's in the hospital. She says he's not doing too well. She says that he's feeling sorry for all the things he did and he wants to apologise. I asked her why wasn't Dave the one who's calling me then. She says that Dave was feeling to weak for that.

[Continues...]

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
[...Continued]

So there's my conundrum. Do I visit him and see what he has to say or do I ignore him and my mother and hope he gets worse. I can see pros and cons to both sides so I want to hear what you think.

BTW: I'm going to therapy so I'm mentally more or less prepared if I ever were to meet Dave again

posts.com: A friend of mine has been posting posts about killing themselves on a near daily basis. I don’t know what to do or say in this situation. I have no intention of reporting them to anyone as that has never gone well in any situation I know of. They’ve gone as far as to post pictures of self harm. As someone who can’t even explain why life is worth living, I’m not sure what to say. Sorry if this came off a bit rambly.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
You're not a therapist and you shouldn't try to act as one. But you can do a couple things as a friend:
1) don't ever call them selfish for all this, if you have to say something, tell them not to despair and gently nudge them into getting help, without pushing it.

2) allow them to talk about their problems, you don't always have to reply with a solution or a bright idea, just listen and understand. If you feel like there's something helpful to say, then say it. If something you hear is truly mind-boggling, it might be better to suggest they repeat that exact thing to a professional (just to give some meaning to the term "get help")

3) give them some time in general, don't give up

Just being an autistic maniac works with a couple caveats. You need a few social skills. Mostly just showing interest in others, not rambling, and learning to not be outwardly judgmental of people so long as they are kind (genuinely kind, be as much of a dick as you want to really passive aggressive people). AND you also kinda sorta have your life together (if 25+).. Emphasis on it only needing to be "kinda sorta" though., I basically just mean you don't live with your parents, aren't obese, and you're above the paycheck to paycheck style of living.

The hard part is learning to feel zero embarrassment for being bombastically weird. It doesn't work if you half-ass it. Expect more people to hate you as well, but the benefits are worth it. If you work a job with a lot of social rules, start viewing your job as nothing more than an exchange of time for money and then completely be yourself outside of work. Environments with a lot of social rules are extremely cucked and, as an autist, there is no social success to be found in such environments unless you're okay with having a very submissive personality.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>28195406

Look up survivor guilt, it's a related state of mind. Really though, you've had several brushes with your own mortality and you now have to sit down and decide what being acutely aware that you're a flimsy sack of wet meat liable to get hurled into oblivion with disturbing ease means.

I was diagnosed with cancer at 23, it put me on the slow and ongoing path to God as I came to see more and more how I'd spent my life up to that point flailing around for an unearned sense of superiority over those around me and expecting a life of ease to be handed to me on a platter. I now spend my time figuring out how I can best exemplify a life well lived to those around me, to be a light burning in the darkness that others may know they are not walking alone in this veil of tears.

What has the nearness of death meant to you? What will you now decide life means to you? You alone have to take whatever path of contemplation and action leads you on an unending journey of self-discovery and humility.

I can think of a few explanations.
The simplest is that you're just finding sluts who for one reason or another are intimidated by or uninterested in a serious relationship.
But you could also be scaring off some girls if you say you take them seriously too quickly (which is in part due to the diseased mentality of parts of society, but there's also a genuine concern about guys who get obsessive), without you getting to know each other well enough. Some girls are also anxious and will try to avoid things that put too much pressure on them, even if they like you.
Another possibility, if you're texting this *very* early on, is that they were never interested to begin with, and you bringing up dating/relationships made them feel compelled to reject you.

Again, if you're dating women with decent values, most of this isn't an issue, since they wouldn't be interested in anything but a serious relationship, but you might still risk coming off too strong with some women. Maybe that's just paranoia on my part, but even on the rare occasion I give some light push back on topics about stupid shit that doesn't even matter people will sometimes take it personally.
Also if I talk too much about the weird nerd shit I can see the soul leaving their body.
It's a fun little balancing act of trying not to offend people, while also not being incredibly boring at the same time.That's why I'm sort of surprised to have met some people in college since most of the time I tend to view myself as a boring pushover.

>>28195592
This may not help, but here is my like advice. idk if it will help, but I hope it makes you feel a little better.

You can't help what is already gone. I wont tell you to just stop thinking about it, because it's not that simple. But you are human, be kind to yourself. You're aloud to not be perfect. There are times in my life I think 'man I was a real bitch'. I'm human, the best I can do is hope to learn from my mistakes and try to be at least a little better.
It may feel like you wasted your life but I think it is important to ask yourself. If I was in the same place I was then, with the same mindset, same level of intelligence that I had back then. Would I have been able to act differently.
I think most of the time we act on what we think is best at the time. It's easy to look back and think off all the ways you could have changed it, but you didn't know what you know now.
You can't change past, but you can start working on your self now. It's not easy, your mind will fight you on it, but it's possible.

There is always going to be someone better than you. There will always be someone better than me. But just because there better doesn't mean that there going to be right person for someone. Just because there is someone better does not negate how great you are.
Not to mention, perfect in my eyes wont be the same perfect in your eyes. Things that I find important wont be important to you. This is fine. That is how we find our people.

To me being a great lover isn't the same as like 'big d, abs, I orgasm in 2 sec'. I think what really matters is that my partner is trying to learn my body and wants me to be satisfied. As I would want to do for them. I simple want my partner to be happy in the bed room and I would want them to want that too. So as long as you try, learn, and find what you both like. I think that is more than enough.

Mate, I'm not the wanker trying to pick up a coworker and unable to come up with a way to start a conversation. Do you really believe trying to insult me is the best means by which to garner my help?

Asking her about what she did over the weekend is a good open. generic, non confrontational question that both allows you to find out about her through her interests (ie what she did in her free time) and gives you something to continue the conversation from when she answers with what she got up to. There is no way that question can be interpreted as sexual harassment and it allows you to gauge interest.

If she gives you a closed answer like "not much" she doesn't want to know you on a personal level and you should keep things professional.

If she says something like "I just stayed at home" you might counter with what you did on the weekend. If that was stayed home too, perhaps you did something interesting at home like saw a movie you really liked, or engaged in a hobby. Talk about that.

If she's interested, then she'll bounce off your reply and ask questions about whatever you did, or relate to what you did with something she enjoys. Congratulations you're having a conversation.

Closed answers means she isn't interested. If she starts giving closed answers just keep things professional.

Here is something a little more practical that might be able to help you with more black and with boundaries.

Don't offer to do anything for her that she isn't asking help with. If you asked about something, don't immediately try to solve it personally. What I mean by that is
#1 don't throw money at her problems, it makes anyone who is not looking to take advantage of you very uncomfortable
#2 don't shift your entire schedule around her. If she is talking about, idk lets say she needs someone to watch her dog. if it fits into your schedule, fine, cool, but if it cuts into your work or something you need/want to do that you had planned, suggest a first you trust to watch the dog or some kind of boarding.
#3 No excessive gifts. Nothing out of the blue outside maybe snack she likes if you are going to meet up. No expensive gifts. Many people have had experiences where they received gift and then it was attempted to be used a leverage to get something from them. Just don't do it. Also nothing that she is super into or you are super into. One suggests a lot of familiarity when your relationship is just starting, and the other comes off and clingy and trying to force your whatever onto her. Not a good look.

After a few months, you can be more honest with how you feel. A lot of people do catch feelings, but if you don't have control over them, no one wants to be with that. You don't have to stop feeling them, but you still have to be able to look at the relationship from an objective level and be able to acknowledge if you two are good for each other or not.
if I was you, the way i would phrase it when yo tell her how you feel is "i really like you, but we have only know each other for so long, so I just want to be careful based on how I feel. but ya I really really like you"

All dating woes can be explained by two simple facts:

1) No one knows anyone’s rules for dating

2) Everyone wants everyone else to follow their rules

I’m not claiming it’s all completely random or anything, but this is where a huge amount of all the Redpill-Bluepill debate comes from.

Bluepillers sorta understand that there aren’t really rules and propose that consent and and communication are the necessary principles to make rules between two people that are ethical and fair

Redpillers have tried that and saw that it didn’t work because all the women they tried to get with didn’t like the fact they had to explain how they wanted a date to happen. They just wanted it to ‘happen’

Now since the Bluepiller told the Redpiller that consent and communication are ‘the way’ (the reason I said ‘sorta’ understand) and ‘the way’ didn’t work they became skeptical of this worldview

I could talk forever about how this culminated in the creation of incels, mgtows and the like, but that’s the basic picture.

They want our culture to have an established set of dating norms that benefit them for a litany of (usually fallacious) reasons. Women’s rights be damned.

Bluepillers aren’t off the hook either. They’ve still only ever made the suggestion of ‘communicating’ and ‘getting consent’ as good principles to establish a set of dating norms at large, but they rarely go into the specifics of it.

Some deny entirely that they are subject to dating norms, but that is ludicrous in my opinion. They have certain social rules that are making them tick like everyone else, and while there’s no ‘right’ or ‘wrong’ answer, there are better and worse answers for the parties involved. There are also answers that sound nice in theory, but will never work out in practice.

For example, a lot of the dating norms we have today are optional for women. (Asking out vs getting asked, paying or going dutch etc.)

TRP has a lot of solid foundational stuff. It extends beyond basic nutrition and fitness too. As a 13/14 yo, finding TRP taught me to stop staring at the ground when I walked, taught me to separate kindness from romance (and more importantly, see why and the nuance behind it), taught me that there were options to how I wanted to live my life, and so on. I would go as far as to say that finding it taught me to think for myself, because I found something that everyone hated but proved to be useful to me.
That being said, TRP has a LOT of negatives and irrational assumptions and can even induce weird psychological complexes. I remember one post by a guy about how he was trying to reconnect with his HS friends and they all went out for drinks in his hometown. They all complemented him because TRP had transformed him (he got fit, got comfy with women, got a better job, etc.), but this poster wasn't able to enjoy it. He spent the entire time trying to "maintain frame" and be the most alpha one at the table, unable to truly reconnect. He acknowledged that it was irrational, but didn't know what to do.
I think at its most simple, I would say that TRP is great for seduction and terrible for romance. Ultimately, a healthy LTR with a life partner requires you to be competent at both.
So basically, you can follow the tips, just don't go overboard.

Old school TRP was a flash in the pan. I hate to say this, and it probably sounds weird, but TRP was ideologically primed to self-destruct. The mantra was to "enjoy the decline," which is well and good in the moment, but we are living 10 or 15 years after that mantra began. The decline is now tangible.
Additionally, the people who grew up reading and doing TRP as young adults or teenagers, those people are now ready to settle down and start families. They might settle for kicking up their heels and enjoying the decline, but they don't want to. TRP's ideas are antithetical to a stable LTR, since the concept behind the seduction technique is to intentionally spike instability to keep things fresh, force her to recommit to you, and develop a DGAF mentality that lets you easily walk away and find new partners.
Basically, TRP knowingly presented itself as not having "all" the answers. It can help you survive the status quo, but it made no attempts to tell you how to prevent further decline, let alone reverse it. This is actually part of the allure, since it ejects the useless politics shit and focuses on actually improving its practitioners, but it makes the ideology behind TRP vulnerable.
TRP has therefore begun being ideologically diluted with black pill thinking, and honestly a degree of blue pill thinking too.

This may sound weird, but people crave the political underpinnings of these things. They don't just want to develop themselves, learn how to do things they want to do, or participate in a community, though those things are nice. They also want to know why they are doing it, why it matters, what it means, and what the community - as a whole - could or should or will do. TRP, for all the good and bad it does, simply does not offer that, so people will seek it elsewhere.

Very interesting question anon. I hope you didn't mean it ironically as some sort of gotcha, because I think you'll find the answer interesting too.
Basically, misogyny and misandry are bad, mkay? Except, in reality, are they bad? We've actually begun testing that theory and we've found that sexism can be split into multiple different categories, or perhaps levels of extremity is another way to think of it. There is 'no sexism,' 'benign sexism,' and 'hostile sexism.' If hostile sexism is like someone sending their love from Kazakhstan, then benign sexism would be men who insist on paying for dates or insist on driving her. We have found that, at least in women, benign sexism is actually linked to the best outcomes, with no sexism taking the second place and hostile sexism producing the worst outcomes.
Now, this research is only preliminary and we haven't studied the effect well for men, but it's interesting to say the least. It suggests that women might be best served by looking for men with a healthy skepticism and respect for the opposite sex, which would explain the seemingly baffling behavior of getting with "misogynistic" men. In reality, these men aren't contemptuous the way we generally think of misogynists. They are misogynistic in that they are patronizing, like a parent to a child.
Remember that we aren't looking for "the one," some spiritual partner we are destined to find and love. At the end of the day, for an LTR, men are looking for a mother to their children and women are looking for a father. We, as men, want our woman to be kind; who couldn't love a mother blessed with grace and warmth? But should a father just be kind? Perhaps, but only from a position of respect and strength. He can be compassionate, but it is not a father's job to defer to others. A woman must know that if someone attacks her or invades your home or anything, you will be there to defend her.
